entries.title: Russian Missile Attack Overwhelms Ukraine’s Air Defenses
entries.description: Cruise missiles and exploding drones from Iran swept across the skies of Ukraine, wreaking havoc and once again knocking out power.

entries.title: How Bad Is China’s Covid Outbreak? It’s a Scientific Guessing Game
entries.description: In the absence of credible information from the Chinese government, researchers around the world are looking for any clues to determine the size and severity of the surge.

entries.title: U.S. Says Chinese Fighter Jet Flew Dangerously Close to American Plane
entries.description: The Chinese jet flew within 20 feet of the nose of an American military aircraft over the South China Sea this month, nearly causing a collision, the U.S. military said.

entries.title: Unlikely Parallels in a Year of Momentous Deaths
entries.description: The deaths of luminaries like Queen Elizabeth II and Bill Russell did not necessarily surprise. Others, though, inscrutably departed seemingly in tandem.

entries.title: Your Friday Briefing: Israel’s New Government
entries.description: Also, Russia strikes Ukraine, Pelé dies and the week in culture.

entries.title: Pelé, the Global Face of Soccer, Dies at 82
entries.description: Pelé, who was declared a national treasure in his native Brazil, achieved worldwide celebrity and helped popularize the sport in the United States.

entries.title: Israel’s Hard-Line Government Takes Office, Testing Bonds with Allies
entries.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s right-wing coalition will likely test ties with the United States and Europe, amid fears that it will undermine the country’s democracy and stability.

entries.title: Algeria Cracks Down on Last Remaining Independent Media Outlet
entries.description: The country has effectively closed down one of the last places in Algeria for freewheeling political debate, which carried on even as the military-backed regime that leads the country grew increasingly authoritarian.

entries.title: Japan’s Ski Mecca, Niseko, Is Desperate for Workers
entries.description: Japan reopened its borders just in time for the winter season. The Niseko area is straining to meet the pent-up demand.

entries.title: Pictures of the Year
entries.description: Some of the most memorable photos published in The Times in 2022.

entries.title: China Covid: U.S. Testing Rule Meets a Collective Shrug
entries.description: The U.S. travel rule drew a muted response in a country grappling with outbreaks and where mass, regular Covid testing was up until recently a daily reality for many millions of people.

entries.title: Moscow on the Med: A Faraway War Transforms a Turkish Resort Town
entries.description: Tens of thousands of Russians and Ukrainians have settled in Antalya, on Turkey’s southern coast, hoping to avoid the fallout of Russia’s war in Ukraine and start new lives.

entries.title: The Biden administration tries to stop Iran from supplying Russia with drones.
Fire at Cambodian Casino Near Thai Border Kills at Least 10
entries.description: The blaze at the Grand Diamond City also injured at least 30 people, officials said. Guests at the 17-story complex leaped from windows to escape the flames.

entries.title: Explosions Rock Kyiv After Ukrainian Officials Warned of New Wave of Strikes
entries.description: It was not clear whether the blasts were from intercepts or strikes by cruise missiles. The authorities had been warning for days that Russia was planning strikes on the electrical grid.

entries.title: Exxon Mobil Sues to Try to Block EU Windfall Tax
entries.description: European subsidiaries of the American oil giant filed a lawsuit with a European Union court seeking to stop the tax, which Exxon Mobil said could cost it billions of dollars.

entries.title: Ukraine gives an optimistic update on its power grid, but concern grows about coming holidays.
Your Thursday Briefing
entries.description: New requirements for passengers coming from China.
